L1_summary_of_paper: The paper develops a dyad-level, action-oriented account of rivalry by asking how multimarket contact (MMC) between two firms shapes their ongoing sequences of market entry into and exit from each other’s markets, and how these effects vary with dyad-specific context. Studying California commuter airlines (1979–1984) after U.S. airline deregulation, the authors define markets as city-pair routes and model yearly counts of firm i’s entries into and exits from competitor j’s incumbent routes. They theorize that MMC produces mutual forbearance via deterrence and tacit coordination, but only after an escalation phase—implying inverted-U relationships between MMC and both entry and exit rates. They further predict that (i) a focal dyad’s MMC effect is contingent on the focal firm’s relative MMC with its other competitors (firms attack low-relative-MMC rivals) and (ii) competitor size asymmetry moderates MMC’s effects (larger rivals amplify deterrence and weaken exit-suppression). Using dyad-year panel Poisson models with rich controls and lagged actions, they find: entry and exit rates peak at moderate MMC, fall at high MMC; lower relative MMC dyads experience higher entry and exit; larger competitor size strengthens MMC’s deterrence of entry and attenuates its damping of exit. Contributions include shifting MMC analysis from market/firm aggregates to dyads, establishing nonlinearity in MMC–rivalry dynamics, and revealing dyad microstructures (relative MMC, size asymmetry) that condition forbearance.
N5_focus_scope: Multiple competitors focus but measureds as dyadic pairs
A1_citation: Baum, J. A. C., & Korn, H. J. (1999). Dynamics of dyadic competitive interaction. Strategic Management Journal, 20(3), 251–278.
C3_metric_detail: Uncertainty not formally measured; regulatory change (deregulation) frames a turbulent competitive context.
C4_shock_design: Post–Airline Deregulation Act context used to define the observation window; not exploited for identification.
D2_identification: Other: Dyad-year Poisson count models with lagged actions and extensive controls
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Conditional independence across dyads after controls
Dynamic dependence captured via lagged entry/exit counts
D5_data_sources: Civil Aeronautics Board annual reports (available seat miles)
1980 U.S. Census of Population (route capacity proxies)
Davies (1982) Airlines of the United States Since 1914 (founding years)
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Dyadic independence relies on controls; overall resource/attention constraints not modeled; MMC may co-move with unobserved rivalry intensity; Poisson choice sensitive to dispersion; no public data/code.
G1_construct_mapping_note: MMC → mutual forbearance potential; dyadic entry/exit → process components of rivalry; relative MMC and size asymmetry → boundary conditions shaping the MMC–rivalry curve.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: MMC’s effect on rivalry is inverted-U and contingent on dyad context.
Relative MMC reallocates competitive effort toward low-contact rivals.
Size asymmetry amplifies deterrence of entry and weakens exit suppression at high MMC.
I1_mechanism_statements: Increasing MMC initially raises incentives to enter/exit via cross-market retaliation options and information gains, but high MMC induces tacit coordination and strategic exit barriers, lowering entry/exit.
Low relative MMC dyads attract competitive attention and resources, increasing entry/exit toward those rivals.
When the competitor is much larger, perceived deterrence from multimarket retaliation rises, reducing entry and weakening MMC’s suppression of exit.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Lower relative MMC increases entry and exit conditional on MMC.
Larger competitor strengthens MMC’s negative slope on entry and attenuates MMC’s negative slope on exit at high MMC.

J1_main_findings_summary: Entry and exit rates relate to MMC in an inverted-U pattern: escalation at low-to-moderate MMC, forbearance at high MMC.
Relative MMC matters: dyads with lower MMC than the focal firm’s other dyads see higher entry and exit.
Competitor size asymmetry moderates MMC effects: larger rivals heighten deterrence against entry and reduce MMC’s damping of exit.
Rivalry exhibits dyad-specific microstructures; firms grapple vigorously with some rivals while remaining passive toward others.
K1_contribution_summary: By relocating MMC to the dyad level and modeling entry/exit dynamics, the paper overturns simple linear forbearance views, establishes an inverted-U baseline for MMC’s effect on competitive interaction, and identifies boundary conditions—relative MMC portfolios and size asymmetry—that explain why firms contest some rivals intensely yet forbear others.
